content: Here's your weekly Investing Action Plan: what you need to know as an investor for the coming week. X Earnings season picks up steam with more big banks reporting, such as Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C) and Goldman Sachs (GS), while tech heavyweight IBM (IBM) could set a major milestone with its quarterly results, and leaders…

Today's cars and SUVs, packed with revolutionary technologies, are nothing like the vehicles of several decades ago. Nor is leadership among the world's largest automakers, including General Motors (GM), Ford Motor (F) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU), as the industry confronts one of the most transformational periods in its history. The upstart, high-tech electric car maker Tesla (TSLA) has raised expectations on innovation,…

At this week's Los Angeles Auto Show, manufacturers are expected to introduce more than 50 brand-new vehicles to the car-buying public.As has been the custom of late, some of the most exclusive names in carmaking — Volkswagen's (VLKAY) Bentley, Bugatti, Ferrari (RACE), McLaren, and Rolls-Royce — are skipping the show altogether in favor of targeted driving and VIP events. That's an increasingly common decision by some of the world's leading luxury brands. Aston Martin and Fiat Chrysler's (FCAU) Maserati group, similarly, will wait until later shows to offer anything new.That doesn't mean all the luxury brands are sitting this one out, though. Others, including Fiat Chrysler's Alfa Romeo, Mercedes-Benz, Jaguar and Volkswagen's Porsche, will offer significant world debuts."The luxury brands are cautiously optimistic this year," said Matt DeLorenzo, the managing editor at Kelley Blue Book. "The market has hit a plateau, with the luxury segment still locked in at 12% of the total market. But on the other hand, it's a great time to be a luxury car buyer because the luxury market is full of options. The L.A. show is going to underscore that with plenty of new introductions."Luxury-auto makers will primarily be showing large sedans, crossovers, and SUVs, the last of which makes sense considering the fact that the U.S. is the world's largest SUV market. Much attention will go to Alfa Romeo, which will introduce its first SUV, the Stelvio, on Wednesday."The Stelvio is a big deal for Alfa Romeo if they really want to get a foothold and reestablish themselves here in the U.S." DeLorenzo said. "That SUV is going to be a make-or-break vehicle for them."Details on the saccharine-sounding rig remain scarce other than the expectation that it will borrow its body design largely from the Giulia. Stelvio will compete against the Audi Q5 and BMW X3. It is expected to go on sale in early 2017.More concretely, Land Rover will show the First Edition Dynamic version of its best-selling Discovery SUV. BMW will show a new X5 xDrive 40e as well as updated models throughout its SUV and sedan lineup. Mercedes-Benz will premiere an AMG E63 Sedan along with an unconfirmed new car from its top-end Mercedes-Maybach line. Ahead of the show, Mercedes-Benz announced its new AMG GLE43 SUV, which will replace the GLE 400.One possible sleeper SUV that could garner some hype for its good looks is the Infiniti QX Sport Inspiration Concept. Nissan's (NSANY) Infiniti has released little information about the car, but preliminary images show that it has the gently rounded hood and sharp side angles of a futuristic luxury carriage.Among domestic makers, General Motors' (GM) Cadillac will bring the 2017 Escalade SUV and the enormous Escala concept sedan it showed briefly in August at the Pebble Beach Concours D'Elegance. The Escala, which takes its name from the Spanish word for "scale," comes with a 4.0-liter V-8 engine and an interior lined in wood and aluminum. Buick will show its new Cascada Convertible, Encore, Envision and LaCrosse.The fact that Cadillac won't put an all-electric or autonomous powertrain in the Escala is surprising given how much hype those two drivetrains typically receive in L.A. press and popular coverage.What's more, the show this year has gone so far as to recast itself as an "auto mobility" show, with the first days of the event featuring seminars and panel discussions on such future transportation issues as autonomous driving, car sharing, and the connected car. The pivot is a way for the L.A. event to compete with the increasingly popular Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, which automakers attend with increasing fervor. But analysts have pointed out a potential conflict with that shift: The purpose of an auto show is primarily to promote cars that consumers can buy in the near, rather than distant, future."Autonomous driving cars are not here yet, that's the problem," DeLorenzo said. "Their hype looms rather large. The purpose of an auto show is to sell cars. You can buy cars with semiautonomous features, but a full hands-free, drive-me-home-type car is still far away."Maybe that's why Tesla has said it will not bring its upcoming Model 3 plug-in electric sedan to the show.Still, buyers looking for green(er) vehicles have plenty to choose from.Cadillac will show the CT6 PHEV, an all-new, rear-wheel electric car producing total system power of 250kW (equivalent to 335 horsepower) and 586 newton metro (roughly 432 pound-feet) of torque. Porsche will add an AWD Panamera Hybrid (priced a bit less than $100,000) to its sedan line, plus two newly efficient engine variants and a host of now-standard creature comforts.Elsewhere, BMW Group's MINI will give the world premier MINI Countryman with a plug-in hybrid option. The BMW brand will also offer a BMW 740e xDrive sedan, BMW 330e, and a massively updated BMW i8 super electric car.BMW won't be the only one to show a new halo car of sorts. Jaguar will also be announcing a totally new halo car at a swanky party before the show, along with showing a $1.4 million Classic XKSS at a separate, off-site event later in the week. Jaguar had announced earlier this year that it would indeed resurrect the classic XKSS, which was originally a two-seat D-Type that won Le Mans three years in a row from 1955 to 1957. The curved work of art is widely considered the world's first supercar.Mercedes will deepen its impressive lineup here with previews of the blisteringly fast AMG GT line: Spots with an AMG GT C Roadster, AMG GT Roadster, and AMG GT R are all planned. What it won't have, Mercedes executives say, is that rumored pickup truck: "While a pickup is under consideration for the U.S. market at some point, no timeline is available for a decision to be made," a spokesman said in an email earlier this week.Along with an A5 Cabriolet, Audi will have a special collector's edition R8 V10 supercar that comes with laser lights.The Los Angeles company Divergent will show its 3D-printed Blade supercar; it claims the car will use a 700-horsepower bi-fuel engine that goes from zero to 60 in two seconds. Another fringe sub-brand, Aria, will show its first concept supercar at an event in downtown L.A. The brand has said the car is a two-door, two-seat, rear-wheel-drive Corvette V-8 engine machine. It will get 650 horsepower and 650 pound-feet of torque on its eight-speed transmission, according to a press statement.Fisker, which announced plans for a new supercar earlier this year, will not show in L.A., although its eponymous founder, Henrik Fisker, echoed the idea that the year will emphasize "electric mobility."There will still be one or two things for track-loving driving enthusiasts, however. Lamborghini will show a new Huracan Spyder rear-wheel drive. The open-top stunner is not a hybrid, and it's certainly not fuel efficient. But the aggressive Huracan will stand out as delightfully analogue among the myriad futuristic green machines expected at L.A.

Like its shelled namesake, fitness gear maker Nautilus (NLS) has learned to live underwater. The stock peaked in May 2002 after a run up of more than 20,800% over the prior five-and-a-half years. It then dropped 99% to a low in February 2009. But that's only part of the stock's flashy history. When Nautilus workout equipment made its way onto…

The stock market opened lower early Wednesday, and the Nasdaq lagged, weighed down by weak earnings from Apple (AAPL) late Tuesday.The Nasdaq lost 0.5%, the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.1% and the S&P 500 fell less than 0.1%.The stock market today opens with the Nasdaq struggling against an undertow caused by Nasdaq 100 bellwether Apple, which dropped more than 7% after reporting its first-ever drop in iPhone sales late Tuesday. Key supplier Broadcom (AVGO) fell hard early but reversed, rising 0.6%.Beyond the Apple effect, investors will be looking toward this afternoon's policy announcement from the Federal Open Market Committee, scheduled for 2 p.m. ET.Pending home sales numbers for March are due out at 10 a.m. from the National Association of Realtors.Crude oil jumped almost 2% early Wednesday after posting a 3% gain on Tuesday. West Texas Intermediate traded just below $45 a barrel. The crude supply report from the American Petroleum Institute on Tuesday showed an unexpected 1.1 million barrel draw on oil inventories. The Energy Information Administration releases its weekly inventories data at 10:30 a.m.The jump in crude prices helped energy stocks outperform in the S&P 500. Meanwhile, S&P 500 component and  IBD 50 stock Michael Kors (KORS) sewed up a 3% gain after Piper Jaffray upgraded the stock to overweight from neutral and lifted Kors' price target to 67 from 54.Take a look at Michael Kors' financial and technical vital signs using IBD's Stock Checkup feature.At the low end of the S&P 500, H&R Block (HRB) and Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT) plunged at the open. Goodyear slumped 6% after reporting a broad Q1 miss. H&R Block  cratered 15% after it forecast flat tax-season revenue after total returns prepared decreased nearly 5%.Early leaders in the Dow included United Technologies (UTX) and Boeing (BA). Boeing added 0.8% even though its Q1 earnings stopped short of analyst consensus views, hurt by a one-time charge related to its KC-46 tanker program. Revenue rose 2%, above expectations.Dreamworks Animation (DWA) spiked 15% on news that Comcast (CMCSA) was in talks to buy the movie maker for more than $3 billion. Comcast also reported stronger-than-expected Q1 earnings. Shares were up almost 3%.Security software developer Fortinet (FTNT) leapt 8% in early trade. The Sunnyvale, Calif., company reported a clean Q1 sales and earnings win late Tuesday.  Shares ended Tuesday up 34% from a February low, climbing the right side of a deep, eight-month correction.Twitter (TWTR) tumbled 16%. The microblogging site's Q1 revenue rose 36%, shy of analyst projections. EPS climbed a better-than-forecast 114%, but management's Q2 revenue guidance missed expectations by a wide margin.

WOW! What a day...the headlines are screaming...not sure what to say first! One of these headlines has to cause some action in the mkt.......Apple, Twitter, Trump, Clinton, Yellen, The FED, The Economy, Oil ???? and the list goes on.....Interestingly enough though - all of these negative headlines are not causing global mkts to go into implosion mode - and while Asian mkts ended the day lower (Apple ) , European mkts are mixed to slightly higher...US Futures this morning are off only 4 pts - which is a bit of a surprise considering all the talk last night after Apple (AAPL) reported a MISS on every line....Revenues, Sales, EPS, Margins etc.....the headlines detail the sentiment"Apple Sinks on IPhone Stumble"
"Apple Shareholders Continue to get Shafted.."
"Is Apple going Rotten"

"Apple's Best Days May be Behind It"Then add in the other headlines grabbing the attention and we wonder - is all of this enough to ignite the mkts? Is any of this enough to create a change in investor psychology? Have investors just had enough with all the negatives?""Twitter Shares Stumble on Disappointing Results"
"Oil's Magic Number Becomes $50/Barrel for Promise of Recovery"
"Donald Trump Routs Rivals in Races"
"Clinton Scores Delegate Hauls with Wins"

"Business Spending Points to Soft Growth"And so Janet has two choices:Speech A - a bit more hawkish - would detail how great everything is (in the face of weaker eco results on a daily basis) and that higher rates are coming - orSpeech B - a bit more dovish - would acknowledge that the s**t is about to hit the fan, rates to remain low, Economic stats continue to be mixed, June is on the table BUT is not a definite, the committee remains vigilant but cautious, weakness in global economies continued concern...... blah, blah, blah...

So which one will she choose to give?Stocks were little changed yesterday as investors/traders held their breath all day waiting on the release of the Apple earnings, the results of the primaries, and speculation over what Janet would say next.....trading was light yet again as the economic data continues to point to growing weakness in the US economy.2 pm today brings us the long awaited FOMC speech......Now do not expect the FED to address any of the politics at all....but you can be sure that Saturday Night Live will have a field day with it.....Technically overbought? From a technical perspective the markets continue to hover in highly overbought territory - if you look closely at the indexes you will see that there is a technical weakening occurring across the broad number of issues despite prices mostly going sideways in April. We can credit the efforts by the FED as we headed into tax season and the April FOMC meeting – especially coming off a disastrous beginning to the 2016 year...now while the 1Q may have been a bit overdone to the downside - this 'forced' rally has clearly taken us well beyond on the upside as well.....which is why we keep struggling at 2100 on the S&P.After yesterday's key earnings disappointments and continued weaker eco data - a Hawkish FOMC speech will be the catalyst the mkt needs to back off.....how can anyone really expect the mkt to surge higher on a hawkish speech in light of all the negative data points? So clearly then, a Dovish speech will cause the algo's to hit the BUY button - sending the mkts higher - but will it change the psychology.....because in the end - a dovish speech at this point in the game (7 yrs) should not be taken as a positive at all...... Tomorrow brings us 1Q GDP and the estimates are all over the place - with some suggesting a negative print while the majority see a barely positive print. Either way - it is NOT suggestive of a strong, robust economy just yet.As noted - yesterday's Durable Goods report was a fairly large disappointment - now while it was positive - it was below expectations while Durable Goods EX transports missed miserably - coming in at -0.2% vs the expected +0.5%.Today's eco data includes Mortgage Apps - reported at -4.1%, Pending Home Sales exp at +0.5% and the big decision at 2 pm. Earnings include BHI, BA, GD, GT, IPP, GCI to name a few...but expect that much of the conversation will be all about Apple.....as nearly every station will be tearing the results apart as they try to connect the dots around the world..... Apple is currently trading down 8 pts or 7.5% at $96.50....it has clearly broken all major support and will have to work hard to hold the line.....US futures are now down 5 pts - while we still remain in the 2080/2100 trading range....now while individual names will get clobbered today.....and the Nasdaq may come under more pressure - both the Dow and the S&P will be less affected. It does not feel like a disaster is looming at all....but as the day progresses - and the speculation builds over what Janet will do - watch as the mkts react.....if they hold steady then expect speech B.....which is exactly what I expect we will hear. That being said - buyers will defend the position - because in the end - has anything really changed? ...None of the headlines are really new.....most of what we are seeing have been the expectations all along.....and we continue to live in La, La land.....Overnight in Asia - mkts all lower - but there was not the Apple implosion that so many expected.....the word is that investors there are much more interested in the comments by the FED as well as the BoJ and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand due out tomorrow. Japan -0.36%, Hong Kong -0.21%, China -0.37% and ASX -0.63%.European mkts are bucking the trend...all in slightly positive territory - seemingly unfazed by the Apple earnings at all.....Banks rallying on the back of some positive forward guidance coming from Barclays. Oil moving higher +1.7% - has now broken thru resistance at $44.23/barrel - paving the way for a surge to the psychological $50 number. FTSE -0.27%, CAC 40 + 0.22%, DAX + 0.32%, EUROSTOXX +0.01%, SPAIN +0.47% and ITALY -0.25%Take Good CareKPFollow Kenny Polcari on Twitter and Kenny Polcari.comKenny Polcari is Vice President and director of NYSE Floor Operations on behalf of O’Neil Securities, Inc., a sister company of Investor's Business Daily. Last year, the New York Police Department’s mounted unit announced that it would move from the Hudson River Pier 76 stable it had occupied for a decade to a new uptown haunt, the Mercedes House. Maybe it was kismet that the new space, which has been home to 1,000 luxury-condo residents since 2011, has an automotive name. A car club -- the car club, if you live near New York -- officially took over the equines’ old spot April 1. It’s kind of a big deal.“While we might be a private club, Classic Car Club has never been elitist,” co-founder Michael Prichinello said recently during a private tour of its new space, which sits at the corner of 34th Street and the West Side Highway. “Now that we’re part of Hudson River Park, we will be increasing our event space and weekend activities, like car shows, gallery exhibits, mechanics, and educational programs for kids.”The Classic Car Club has been a gear head fixture for 11 years. It offers 38 supercars, including a McLaren 570S, BMW (BAMXY) i8, Shelby GT350, Lamborghini Huracan, ’66 Ford (F) GT, and an ’89 Lancia Delta rally car, plus a bunch of track-ready 911 GTs, all available to drive. If you're counting, that's well over $1 million worth of high-end autos. Its just-vacated far West SoHo space was one of the go-to spots for car parties, debuts and networking events for the automotive industry. This year alone it has hosted debuts for new Singer Design vehicles, Cadillac launches, and McLaren unveilings.The club works thusly: Members pay $180 in monthly dues and then must purchase “points” that buy them driving days for the car of their choice. A year of driving typically costs $9,000, plus dues, for 35 days behind the wheel. There’s no additional insurance fee; just make sure you return the car with a full tank of gas.Everything inside the SoHo space had been private, including the bar and lounge. And membership to the club was capped at 450 people. That will change, Prichinello said.The new club is bigger, with 28,000 square feet of internal space vs. the old club’s 9,400, plus additional parking and a 15,000-square-foot outside patio area, a quarter of which is right on the water. The old space held dozens of horses and offices for 20 officers. It had radiant-floor-heated stalls for each horse, plus a dirt-floor riding arena under a white dome out front; a hay loft dropped hay from a high attic area directly down to the main floor. That column-free warehouse is now the main showroom, with 31-foot-high ceilings and giant windows out onto the Hudson. Walking around the space, it was easy to see how the old police stalls -- with the hay loft and horse showers removed -- would afford ample sunlight and climate-controlled elegance, basically a state-of-the-art car gallery or museum. This time around, the public can finally have access to many of the cars, too (for looking, not driving).Prichinello said the club will start offering storage for an additional 20 classic and collectible cars (a MX-5 Miata, Mercedes AMG GT, and 2017 Ford GT are due to join the ranks in the next months), plus storage for boats and paddle boards and immediate water access on a reclaimed public beach. The club won’t provide kayaks for that beach, but people can store small watercraft there without having to buy a membership. A full cafe operated by the club and some educational rooms will operate toward the front of the building, accessible from the popular jogging and cycling trail that runs the length of Manhattan’s West Side Highway. There will still be a bar, for members only, inside a private lounge.The renovation will add tall windows, green areas, and places to sit right off the jogging trail so the formerly closed-off space is easily accessible to anyone who wants to ogle a cool car.Prichinello and two co-founders will allow an additional 25 members to join as driving members and extend “Club House” membership to 1,000 people. The latter grants access to the member lounge and the event space but keeps driving rights restricted.Club House membership costs $180 a month, with the price expected to exceed $200 later this year. Applications for those open Wednesday, with new members to be inducted in several batches during the summer and fall. (That may be a good option for getting in on this new version of the Classic Car Club early, since the waiting list for driving memberships is four-months long.)Development on the reconstruction has already started; most will be done by the end of the year. Rather than a grand opening, Prichinello said, he’ll host a series of dinners in the new main gallery for VIPs and friends of the club.It’s a smart move to do a few of those special suppers, especially considering that all anyone will want to do anyway is just sit with the cars and pick the one they want to drive. Prichinello is fully aware of the demand. It’s a blessing and a curse.“There will be a few new vintage convertibles for the summer,” he said, smiling. “Those we buy when the right one surfaces. We’re currently on the hunt.”

MARKETS REMAIN IN TURMOIL - US FUTURES are lower again this morning....down 6 pts at 6 AM - after a tough day yesterday.......European mkts are struggling to hang on, Italian banks getting slaughtered - after having lost a combined value of $45 bil this year as concerns rise over 'unprovisioned loans' potentially impairing the solvency of their banking system... a…

Stocks shifted into staggered losses as trade bucked higher on Friday, with earnings results and oil prices stirring a fair share of early action.The Dow and the S&P 500 slipped 0.6% apiece. The Nasdaq narrowed its early decline to trade a fraction lower, aided by a rally among chip equipment stocks.Volume rose sharply as options expirations drove early trade up 53% on the NYSE and 16% higher on the Nasdaq.Today's weak start was the stock market's first dip out of the starting gates in this holiday-shortened week. For the week, indexes still hold solid gains, with the Dow trading up 2%, the Nasdaq ahead by 2.8%, and the S&P 500 showing a 2.1% gain. The options expiration trade clouded the view a bit into behavior among institutional investors, as bulls are generally on the lookout for quiet action while leading stocks build bases.Oil prices contributed to the market's early weakness with West Texas Intermediate slipping more than 3%, back below $30 per barrel to traded effectively flat for the week. Baker Hughes (BHI) releases its weekly rig count data at 1 p.m. ET.Nearly all of the Dow index stocks traded lower, with Boeing (BA) and Chevron (CVX) at the bottom of the list, nearing 2% declines. Advancers held to gains of less than 0.2%.Chip equipment makers headed the S&P 500 as Applied Materials (AMAT) rose more than 9% after a narrow fiscal Q1 sales and earnings beat, followed by better-than-expected guidance. Lam Research (LRCX) and KLA-Tencor (KLAC) were next in line with gains of 5% and 3%, respectively.Yahoo (YHOO) also figured into the mix, jumping 3% after announcing it had formed a committee of independent directors and enlisted services of JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs and PJT Partners to explore strategic options. The company has been vexed over whether and how to spin off its stake in China's Alibaba Holdings (BABA), valued at nearly $40 billion.Among IBD 50 stocks, Surgical Care Affiliates (SCAI) popped more than 2% after its Q4 earnings met, and revenue easily topped consensus forecasts. The stock has been fighting to hold above its 10-week moving average as well as a 41.09 buy point since a mid-January breakout.Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT) retreated 3%, slipping to the bottom of the list. The heavy volume slip sent shares back below their 10-week moving average.IBD 50 stocks are screened according to a broad array of industry- and market-leading fundamental and technical traits.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Stock futures held healthy gains as the market prepared on Tuesday to roll out for a holiday-shortened week of trade. Dow futures were steady, 230 points above fair market value, suggesting an opening gain of around 1.4%.
S&P 500 futures traded up 28 points, and Nasdaq 100 futures snapped up 66 points — 1.6% above Friday's close.
The stock market today took some of its early strength from overseas markets, which climbed after data released on Monday showed China's Q4 GDP growth slowed to its lowest mark in a quarter-century.

That sounds bad, but the 6.8% GDP gain remained within the government's target boundaries and stirred some relief among those expecting more dour results. China's markets surged, possibly also aided by speculation of further government stimulus intervention. The Shanghai Composite leapt 3.2% on Tuesday. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index swung up 2.1%.

The rally skipped Tokyo's Nikkei, which added 0.6% Tuesday after a 1.1% slip on Monday. Europe's markets were in an optimistic mode, with leading indexes in London, Frankfurt and Paris all up more than 2% near midday.

Oil prices were uneven, with West Texas Intermediate up 1% and Brent crude almost 4% higher, but both still trading below $30 a barrel. Gold slipped and other metals rose, with copper grabbing a 3% gain.

A big week for housing news kicks off with the January Builder Confidence Index from the National Association of Home Builders at 10 a.m. ET. The Treasury Department reports long-term Treasury International Capital flow at 2 p.m.

Some interesting early stock moves included a 12% spike by electrical utility AES (AES). Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT) ran up 9%. Jewelry retailer Tiffany (TIF) slumped 4% after announcing its global same-store-sales slipped 6% during the Christmas season. It lowered its full-year EPS guidance and now expects a 10% decline for 2016.
Earnings season picks up momentum this week, with IBM (IBM), Netflix (NFLX), Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and Cree (CREE) all scheduled to report after today's close.

Bank of America (BAC) jumped 2% after reporting Q4 EPS narrowly above and revenue a shade below consensus expectations. Revenue from investments made modest gains while net chargeoffs also increased to $1.1 billion, up from less than $1 billion a year ago.

Morgan Stanley (MS) climbed 4% after its Q4 report. The investment bank turned to profit from loss during the period, and earnings easily topped consensus projections. Revenue declined less than expected. Both Bank of America and Morgan Stanley are wrestling with deepening consolidations.

New Oriental Education & Technology (EDU) shares were unchanged as investors reviewed a fiscal second-quarter report showing earnings and revenue easily topped analyst expectations while student enrollments soared 35% during the quarter. Management's Q3 revenue guidance was in line with consensus projections. New Oriental has posted three tight weekly closes, ending Friday 17% below its Dec. 15 high.Stock futures held healthy gains as the market prepared on Tuesday to roll out for a holiday-shortened week of trade. Dow futures were steady, 230 points above fair market value, suggesting an opening gain of around 1.4%. A pair of automotive suppliers heading in different directions — Johnson Controls (JCI) and Delphi Automotive (DLPH) — topped quarterly earnings views Thursday but fell short on revenue, pushing shares lower.Likewise, Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT) also topped profit views and fell shy on sales.Johnson Controls logged adjusted earnings of $1.04 a share for its fiscal fourth quarter, which ended in September. That was up from 91 cents the prior year and 3 cents above consensus analyst views. Revenue fell 13% to $8.7 billion, below estimates.The No. 1 U.S. auto parts supplier guided fiscal 2016 Q1 earnings of 80 cents to 83 cents a share. That's below the 84 cents expected by analysts prior to Thursday's earnings report.Johnson Controls looks to reduce its automotive supply business so it can focus more on growing its battery-manufacturing and building heating and cooling segments. In July, the company announced plans to spin off its low-margin automotive-interiors business segment into a separate publicly traded entity.In contrast, Delphi continues to expand its auto business. In its third-quarter earnings release Thursday, the company announced the acquisition of Control-Tec, a provider of software that analyzes vehicle testing events during the late stages of product development. This technology lets original equipment manufacturers reduce testing cycles, meet launch schedules and reduce warranty exposure.Delphi reported Q3 adjusted earnings of $1.28 a share, up from $1.16 a year earlier and a penny above estimates. Revenue fell 3.5% and came in below views, as unfavorable currency impacts offset continued volume growth, mainly in North America and Europe.The company guided full-year earnings of $5.15 to $5.25 a share, below analyst views of $5.30.Delphi's stock price sank 7.1% on the stock market today. Johnson Controls lost 1.3%.Goodyear shares declined 4.8% after it beat Q3 EPS views by 2 cents but missed on revenue, as its top line also was hit by unfavorable currency exchanges. Goodyear's stock price set a multiyear high of 33.42 on Wednesday.Follow Vance Cariaga on Twitter: @IBD_VCariaga.
"Fed Keeps December Rate Hike In Play - Officials remove explicit mention of concern at overseas tumult, delivering warning to markets" - WSJ 10-29-15
The operative word in that headline is 'Play'....in this case Play is defined as 'engaging in activity for enjoyment or fun - to amuse oneself'
"Federal Reserve officials explicitly said they might raise short term interest rates in December pushing back against investors who have bet that the central bank wouldn’t move this year."

They continue to try and convince us that they are going to move in 2015....and December is their last opportunity.......but can they really?  US macro data continues to weaken,  The U6 Underemployment rates is still above 10%, inflation remains frustratingly low,  congress just approved a disastrous 'spending plan' kicking their responsibility into the NEXT CENTURY,  The ECB announces a new bigger & better QE type program to further stimulate that sagging economy, and China?  Well they cut short term lending rates last week in a last ditch effort to 'boost growth' while they continue to threaten another currency devaluation.....and Hilsenrath thinks that these moves signal 'STRENGTH'.........and pave the way for the FED to raise rates?   Now in a move to show us how serious they really are - the FED " struck from their policy statement a sentence introduced in September that pointed to market turbulence and global developments as potential restraints on U.S. economic activity. As those concerns recede, the Fed has fewer impediments standing in the way of a rate increase."

Now the funny thing is that the FED is clearly split....some say go, while other say no.......and yesterday's statement was supposed to remove any doubt at all about the coming increase.   Remember - the FED remains 'data dependent' so we will get two more months of 'data' before the FED meets again on Dec 16th/17th.....but remember - they may have wanted to send 'that wakeup call' but in the end - yesterday's statement DID NOT commit to a December move.....(they left the door slightly ajar so that they have an exit plan....)

And amuse themselves is exactly what they did.....Stocks rallied early on prior to 'the announcement'  - the DOW was up 131 pts at 2 pm.....then the news hits...the mkts stumbles as it dissects the headline...then the algo's hit......sending stocks into a minor tailspin sending the DOW  - down 287 pts - from hi to lo.....in a matter of 13 mins.....only to reverse and surge higher into the close as the 'smart algos' realized that the statement didn't really say anything new...there was NO definitive decision....there was nothing in there that sets the path for a move in December at all.....Yeah - there was a vague reference to a move - but does anyone really believe it to be true?  Not yesterday anyway...as they closed the mkt on its highs  at 2090 on the S&P and 17,779 on the DOW..... You gotta love when the FED speaks out of both ends, no?

It is interesting to think that all of a sudden the FED thinks that economy is ready to launch..... Remember!  The Fed hasn’t raised interest rates since 2006 - (they have only lowered them)  and here 9 yrs later  when we have zero interest rates (while some countries have negative rates)  - we also have manufacturing crashing, durable goods and retail sales plunging our national debt approaching $19 trillion, housing still struggling, healthcare costs soaring, wages stagnating,  entitlement programs exploding, Underemployment still in the double digits, weak commodity prices, struggling global economies, half the world in recession and the other half gasping for air and NOW she thinks it's the right time to launch?   Is it me?  Now all this says is that monetary policy alone cannot solve the world's problems....so I once again point the finger at leadership.....or lack of...but hey...that's a conversation for another time I guess.....
In the end - The FED made it clear that they won't raise rates until they are 'reasonably confident' that the data supports the move.....and that ain't happening in 60 days.....

Technically  - the mkt has enjoyed a surge off the August lows...making everyone 'feel better' but is it really better?   Have we moved too fast and now need to play catch up?  I think that answer is yes....and as the mkt gets used to the latest FED speak and analysts/strategists recalculate the possibilities - I suspect that we see the mkt back and fill..... Last night we ended at S&P 2090.....a good 30 pts above support.....earnings are coming to an end and so the focus will return to more broader global macro issues once again....For now - I think we are in the 2060/2100 range...and if the 'data' continues to disappoint then expect the mkt to find its legs and push higher (indicating NO rate increase) ....but if as Janet indicates - the 'data' becomes stronger -then yes....look for the mkt to back off as the reality of an 'increase' hits home....and the mkt re-prices.  Either way - I do not think we get a move in 2015...so I suspect that the mkt churns and attempts to return closer to the yearly highs (2150)  as we approach year end.

Now this morning - US futures are off 8 pts  as we await the first release of 3rd QTR GDP...and it does not have a 3 handle on it, and it does not have a 2 handle on it......we will be lucky if it has a 1 handle on it...as the Atlanta FED suggests it will be 0.9% (vs. the robust 3.9% in the 2nd qtr) and some of the biggest investment banks in the country are looking for 1.2% - 1.4% .  The 'official' (govt) expectation is for a reading of +1.6%.... and if it comes in stronger then I think someone will have 'a lot of 'splainin to do' ......
Look for earnings today from MasterCard (MA),Western Union  (WU), CME Group  (CME),Air Products  (APD), Good Year Tires  (GT), Coca Cola  (KO), Pitney Bowes  (PBI),  and Marathon Oil  (MRO).....

European mkts are in negative territory.....not big, but a bit softer....earnings are the focus.......DBK reports a loss of $6.5 bil  and said that they will CUT their workforce by some 26k jobs over the next 2 yrs - sending that stock lower.........Barclays also missed on their earnings....sending that stock down 4.5%... Frances Total Oil reports a 69% drop in revenue....(no surprise)  and they take the stock UP......Take good care. Kp

After a three-month-long correction, the Nasdaq composite index followed through on May 27. That means it's time to look for stocks breaking out of sound bases.But mutual funds have already been busy in recent months, their buying helping to form the right side of the stock basing patterns.The top-performing funds of the past three months have been big buyers in their latest reporting periods of chipmakers such as Avago Technologies (AVGO), Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) and Cavium (CAVM).Top-performing sectors recently have been defensive areas, including auto-related issues Lydall (LDL), Meritor (MTOR) and Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT).Managers of leading funds have continued to add to their transportation holdings Southwest Airlines (LUV), Alaska Air Group (ALK) and Spirit Airlines (SAVE).In other industries, the ubiquitous K-cup coffee giant Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) has garnered big money from top funds.IBD found 59 top-notch funds loading up on Actavis (ACT), investing an estimated $145 million in their latest reporting periods.Two A+ rated funds, $36.3 billion Vanguard Health Care Fund and $5.9 billion Fidelity Select Health Care Portfolio Fund, owned big stakes in the firm.The Ireland-based company makes and distributes generic and branded drugs for hypertension, pain, sleep disorder and contraception. To boost its portfolio of products, especially in their branded-drug area, it made a big purchase earlier this year, buying rival Forest Laboratories in a deal valued at $25 billion.After reaching a 52-week high of 230.77 on Feb. 26, the stock has been etching the right side of a later-stage base. It's currently sitting just 6% off its high.Actavis has been growing earnings at a healthy double-digit pace in at least the past five quarters. Revenue growth has also been robust in the 20% range for the same period.The drug firm's first-quarter earnings shot up 75%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see a 44% rise in profits for the year.Sell SideThe nation's top funds have been unloading managed-care giants Aetna (AET), WellPoint (WLP) and United Healthcare (UNH) in their latest reporting periods.Earnings growth for each of these three firms has been slowing and inconsistent in the past four quarters.

Major averages strengthened and were near sessions highs with a little more than one hour remaining in Thursday's session.The Nasdaq led the way, rising 0.8%. The S&P 500 added 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.4%. Nasdaq volume was tracking 15% higher than Wednesday. NYSE volume was tracking about equal with Wednesday.The market was spooked early by sluggish economic data before the open. Weekly jobless claims rose to 339,000, slightly above the consensus estimate of 330,000. Meanwhile, January retail sales fell 0.4% (estimate -0.1%). Excluding autos, sales were flat (estimate +0.1%).In the stock market today, Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT) had a solid day, up 11% to a 52-week high. The tire maker reported solid earnings thanks to strength in its core North American market. Goodyear cleared an 11-week consolidation in January, then promptly fell below its 10-week moving average.In merger and acquisition news, Time Warner Cable (TWC) surged 7% after Comcast (CMCSA) announced plans to buy the company for $45 billion. Shares of Comcast fell 4%.WhiteWave Foods (WWAV) gapped out of a short consolidation, rising 8.5%. Earlier today, the company reported better-than-expected Q4 earnings. Profit rose 22% from a year ago and sales rose 12% to $679.3 million. WhiteWave is a provider of plant-based foods and beverages, including soy and almond milk products, under the Silk, Alpro and Provamel brands.Inside the IBD 50, Generac Holdings (GNRC) soared 13% after the company reported strong earnings and issued a bullish outlook. Generac showed compelling technical action Thursday, gapping above its 50-day moving average.Web.com Group (WWWW) continued to rally after recent volatility. Shares rose 3%. The provider of Internet services for small- and medium-size businesses reported earnings last week.A recent cup-with-handle breakout over 32.58 had a hard time getting going. It's gaining traction, though, as shares hit an all-time high Thursday. It's now 5% above the buy point, but recent gains have come in soft trade.
Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT) reported fourth-quarter sales results under analyst estimates Tuesday on weak sales in Europe, but earnings beat.

The tire company's Q4 earnings fell 20% to 59 cents per share, but beat the 58 cents that analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting. Revenue fell 9% to $4.35 billion, slightly under views of $4.36 billion.
Replacement tire shipments were down 4%. Sales of winter tires in Europe were lower due to one of the warmest winters on record.
But North American operating profit rose, helped by lower raw material and pension costs.
Shares jumped in early trading.
"We delivered record full-year segment operating income, successfully navigating a challenging global economic environment," CEO Richard Kramer said in the earnings release.
Goodyear reaffirmed its 2015 earnings growth target of 10%-15% above 2014 results. Analysts are expecting 7% growth.

Cooper Tire & Rubber (CTB) badly missed analyst earnings estimates and reported a year-over-year drop in fourth-quarter revenue amid weakness across both Western and Eastern Europe.

The tire company earned 45 cents per share minus one-time items, vs. break-even results a year ago, on a 5% decline in revenue to $819.6 million. Wall Street expected EPS of 64 cents on $804.1 million in revenue.
Including a one-time gain on the sale of its 65% stake in a joint venture in China, Cooper Chengshan Tire Co. (CCT), Cooper Tire & Rubber earned $1.39 per share vs. 31 cents a year ago.

Shares fell 5.1% to 35.78 in late afternoon trading on the stock market today, after the stock hit its highest since May 1993 on Friday. Cooper stock fell as low a 34.13 intraday, briefly piercing its 50-day moving average.

Among other large companies in the Auto/Truck-Tires & Miscellaneous group, which is ranked a weak 123 on IBD's list of 197 industries, Michelin (MGDDY) fell 0.7%. Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT) slid 2.1%, and Titan International (TWI) was off 2.4%.
Cooper Tire CEO Roy Armes said the company looks to fill the void left by the sale of its share of the China joint venture.

"We are looking to invest in Asia to expand our business after the sale of CCT," he said. "Until that time, we will see the impact of a higher cost structure on our operating profit. In Western Europe markets have softened, and we expect continued volatility in Russia and Eastern Europe."
U.S. net sales rose 10% to $689 million, while international sales declined 33% to $191 million, largely reflecting the loss of sales from the CCT joint venture.

The company expects rising costs to hit its 2015 profit despite continued low commodity purchase costs. Still, "In 2015, we expect the tire markets to continue to grow modestly in North America despite the weakness in Europe," Armes said.

Stocks extended losses midday Thursday, a day after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. The S&P 500 fell 0.8%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq were each down 0.7%.
Volume was running higher on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq compared to the same time Wednesday.

Economic news was mixed, with unemployment claims falling a little less than expected in the week ended Dec. 12, while manufacturing in the mid-Atlantic region fell much more than expected in December. The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators rose 0.4% in November, down from the prior month's 0.6% increase but ahead of analysts' forecasts.
Mining and energy stocks were hit hardest in the stock market today on declines in oil and metals prices.
Newmont Mining (NEM), a Colorado-based miner of gold and silver, lost 8%, leading the S&P 500 lower. Oil transportation stock Oneok (OKE) also dropped about 8%.

Most IBD 50 stocks were lower, led by Global Payments (GPN), which fell more than 2% in heavy volume. The stock plunged 8% on Wednesday, slicing through its 50-day line, after agreeing to buy rival credit card payments processor Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.
Total System Services (TSS), another credit card payments processor in the IBD 50, fell 2.7% but remains well above a 48.18 buy point of a cup-with-handle base that it cleared in October.
But Chinese social media stock Weibo (WB) was a bright spot. It jumped more than 4% in heavy volume, closing in on a 20.80 buy point of a deep, cup-shaped base.

The stock boasts a rising Relative Strength line and an Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A, indicating strong demand for the shares. The stock has more than doubled since falling to a low of 8.78 on Aug. 24.Stocks extended losses midday Thursday, a day after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. The 2015 Detroit Auto Show kicked off with General Motors (GM) showing off the Chevrolet "Bolt EV," a concept electric car for about $30,000 with over 200 miles of range per battery charge. It might rival the mass market Model 3 that Tesla Motors (TSLA) plans to build down the road.

"We have made tremendous strides in technologies that make it easier and more affordable for Chevrolet customers to integrate an all-electric vehicle in their daily lives," GM CEO Mary Barra said in the press announcement. "The Bolt EV concept demonstrates General Motors' commitment to electrification and the capabilities of our advanced EV technology."

Tesla CEO Elon Musk is scheduled to speak at 4:45 p.m. Eastern on Tuesday at The Automotive News World Congress, among a lineup of industry executives, and about an hour after Scott Painter, the CEO of car-buying site TrueCar (TRUE), a recent IPO.

New luxury SUV crossovers are among many vehicle introductions at the Detroit Auto Show — they include the Mercedes-Benz GLE Coupe from Daimler (DDAIF), and from Tata Motors (TTM) the Jaguar brand's first SUV, the F-PACE.

Among a busy slate of introductions, on Monday Ford (F) debuted its GT carbon-fiber supercar, a two-seater with 600-plus horsepower from its twin-turbocharged EcoBoost V6 engine. Ford designed the EcoBoost line of engines for fuel savings and performance in its more accessible vehicles, say the Escape SUV.

"The GT is one of more than 12 new Ford Performance vehicles coming by 2020. It joins Focus RS, F-150 Raptor, Shelby GT350 and Shelby GT350R in the growing Ford Performance lineup," Ford said in a press announcement Monday.

Monday and Tuesday are press preview days before the North American International Auto Show 2015, as it's formally known, opens to the public Jan. 17-25. Last year's show featured 50 vehicle debuts.The 2015 Detroit Auto Show kicked off with General Motors (GM) showing off the Chevrolet "Bolt EV," a concept electric car for about $30,000 with over 200 miles of range per battery charge. GT Advanced Technologies has reached a settlement agreement with Apple (AAPL) under which GT will exit the sapphire glass manufacturing business and pay back Apple for the money it was advanced.

GT Advanced filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Oct. 6. The Merrimack, N.H.-based company reportedly was having problems producing sapphire display covers for future iPhones and Apple Watches, and was missing milestones under its supply agreement with Apple.

Under the agreement announced Thursday , GT Advanced will exit from the market as a producer of sapphire materials and will refocus its business as an equipment supplier, manufacturing and developing sapphire growth systems and processes. As such, it will wind down sapphire materials production at its Mesa, Ariz., and Salem, Mass., locations.

If the agreement is approved by the bankruptcy court, GT Advanced will retain ownership of all production, ancillary and inventory assets located at the Mesa factory and will sell its advanced sapphire furnaces to repay Apple. GT will reimburse Apple for its $439 million prepayment over a period of up to four years without interest. The agreement will release GT from "all exclusivity obligations under its various agreements with Apple."
The agreement also allows GT to retain control of its intellectual property.
GT and Apple will continue their technical exchange involving the development of processes for growing next-generation sapphire boules, GT said in a press release.

"We are pleased with the settlement that we have negotiated with Apple," GT Advanced CEO Tom Gutierrez said in a statement. "We realize that our filing for Chapter 11 protection has caused uncertainty and hardship for many of our important stakeholders. We have been working diligently to develop a restructuring plan that will allow us to emerge from Chapter 11 as quickly as possible and with the operating flexibility and resources to position GT for long-term success.
"This agreement with Apple is an important step in that direction, as it will allow us to monetize our advanced sapphire growth and fabrication technologies in an unrestricted manner."

The agreement provides for a mutual release of any and all claims by both parties, GT said. GT will file a motion seeking bankruptcy-court approval of the settlement agreement on Monday. The court is scheduled to hear the motion on Nov. 25.

After GT Advanced filed for bankruptcy, Pacific Crest Securities analyst Weston Twigg said it was possible that Apple could take possession of the sapphire furnaces it funded and gain access to GT intellectual property that would allow Apple to produce sapphire display covers on its own.

In a bankruptcy-court filing, GT said that its agreements with Apple to make sapphire for iPhone screens were "oppressive and burdensome," the Wall Street Journal reported. "The cash burn at (GT's) sapphire-manufacturing operations for the benefit of Apple is not sustainable," GT said.

The bankruptcy-court case had threatened to expose details of Apple's business dealings with suppliers. Apple was pushing to keep its contracts with GT Advanced secret, the San Jose Mercury-News reported.GT Advanced Technologies has reached a settlement agreement with Apple (AAPL) under which GT will exit the sapphire glass manufacturing business and pay back Apple for the money it was advanced.GT Advanced filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Oct. 6. The Merrimack, N.H.-based company reportedly was having problems producing sapphire display covers for future iPhones and Apple Watches, and was missing milestones under its supply agreement with Apple.Under the agreement announced Thursday , GT Advanced will exit from the market as a producer of sapphire materials and will refocus its business as an equipment supplier, manufacturing and developing sapphire growth systems and processes. As such, it will wind down sapphire materials production at its Mesa, Ariz., and Salem, Mass., locations.If the agreement is approved by the bankruptcy court, GT Advanced will retain ownership of all production, ancillary and inventory assets located at the Mesa factory and will sell its advanced sapphire furnaces to repay Apple. GT will reimburse Apple for its $439 million prepayment over a period of up to four years without interest. The agreement will release GT from "all exclusivity obligations under its various agreements with Apple."The agreement also allows GT to retain control of its intellectual property.GT and Apple will continue their technical exchange involving the development of processes for growing next-generation sapphire boules, GT said in a press release."We are pleased with the settlement that we have negotiated with Apple," GT Advanced CEO Tom Gutierrez said in a statement. "We realize that our filing for Chapter 11 protection has caused uncertainty and hardship for many of our important stakeholders. We have been working diligently to develop a restructuring plan that will allow us to emerge from Chapter 11 as quickly as possible and with the operating flexibility and resources to position GT for long-term success."This agreement with Apple is an important step in that direction, as it will allow us to monetize our advanced sapphire growth and fabrication technologies in an unrestricted manner."The agreement provides for a mutual release of any and all claims by both parties, GT said. GT will file a motion seeking bankruptcy-court approval of the settlement agreement on Monday. The court is scheduled to hear the motion on Nov. 25.After GT Advanced filed for bankruptcy, Pacific Crest Securities analyst Weston Twigg said it was possible that Apple could take possession of the sapphire furnaces it funded and gain access to GT intellectual property that would allow Apple to produce sapphire display covers on its own.In a bankruptcy-court filing, GT said that its agreements with Apple to make sapphire for iPhone screens were "oppressive and burdensome," the Wall Street Journal reported. "The cash burn at (GT's) sapphire-manufacturing operations for the benefit of Apple is not sustainable," GT said.The bankruptcy-court case had threatened to expose details of Apple's business dealings with suppliers. Apple was pushing to keep its contracts with GT Advanced secret, the San Jose Mercury-News reported.
Cooper Tire & Rubber (CTB) streaked past Wall Street expectations on Friday, with solid Q3 earnings gains compared with breaking even last year.
The tire manufacturer earned 77 cents a share and grew revenue 10.5% to $920 million.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected earnings of 72 cents on revenue of $912 million.
Shares rose 0.7% to 33.36 on the stock market today in morning trade.

Cooper noted that while there was a stark increase in EPS this quarter, Q3 2013 was "impacted by a number of unusual circumstances," which results in year-over-year comparisons that are "not representative of the business under normal conditions."

Those circumstances include labor actions at its joint venture operations in China, Cooper Chengshan Tire Co. (CCT) and costs related to a then-pending merger which was subsequently terminated, the company said.
CTB reported net loss of $168,000 in Q3 2013, which resulted in zero earnings.
"Our third quarter performance continued the solid trends we saw during the first half," said president and CEO Roy Armes.

"Even after adjusting for the unusual issues last year, we had strong unit volume growth, particularly in the Americas segment. The 14-percent overall unit growth, along with declining raw material costs, allowed us to post an operating margin of 9.7 percent, which is at the high end of our target range."

The Americas segment captured $694 million in sales, a 9.6% increase from last year. Unit shipments in the Americas climbed 11%, Cooper said, adding that volume growth was driven primarily by sales of new, higher margin passenger and light truck products introduced in the past year.
In the International segment, sales jumped 18.6% to $313 million. The increase reflects $116 million from the absence of volume related to the CCT labor issues.
Cooper said that its joint venture partner, Chengshan Group, intends to acquire its 65% stake, and Cooper is proceeding with the proposed sale of interest.
"China will continue to be an important part of Cooper's long-term growth strategy whether or not we own the joint venture," said Armes.
Raw material costs declined about 2% from Q2. Cooper said it expects Q4 material costs to decline even more.
Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT), which last week missed revenue estimates, rose 4 cents to 25.19 in morning trade.

In a press release , GT said it expects to conduct business as usual while it works out a reorganization plan and addresses its financial issues. Nasdaq temporarily halted trading in GT stock as it awaited receipt of…

As a chemical engineer at Goodyear Co. in 1900, Paul Litchfield was struggling with a tire design when he recalled something he saw in a New England seaport. When tossed by wind and waves, a ship rode easily at dock when it was held to the snubbing block of the wharf by ropes. Had the ship been held by steel…
Stock futures upshifted modestly ahead of Tuesday's open, after some positive GDP numbers from the Commerce Department.
Dow futures moved up to 34.1 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures rose 7.2 points and S&P 500 futures gained 3.8 points.

The stock market today gets underway with a boost from Q3 economic growth estimates. The Commerce Department revised its view of third-quarter GDP growth upward to 3.9% vs. its initial 3.5% estimate. Economists had projected a downward revision to 3.3% growth. The department also notched up its GDP deflator, a measure of prices across the economy, to a 1.4% increase, compared to an initial view of 1.3%. Consensus views expected prices to strengthen 1.3%.

Housing markets will get a strong dose of data this morning, with the Case Shiller 20-City Home Price Index and the Federal Housing Finance Agency's Housing Price Index, both for September, due out at 9 a.m. ET. The Conference Board is also lined up to deliver its November Consumer Confidence Index at 10 a.m.
A handful of stocks were in motion on early earnings news. DSW (DSW) gained 6%. Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT) climbed 3%.
Jewelry was in the early spotlight, with Signet Jewelers (SIG) up 5% and Tiffany (TIF) ahead 2% after their third-quarter reports.

Signet, which is still digesting its $1.5 billion acquisition of Zale completed in May, reported earnings down 50%, less than the forecast 57% drop. Revenue climbed 53%, in line with estimates. The stock ended Monday at a new closing high, working on its seventh straight weekly gain.

Tiffany earnings came up a bit short of expectations, and 5% revenue growth missed by an even wide span. But a big jump in gross margin and rising investment in information technology systems apparently pleased investors. The stock ended Monday just below a 105.76 buy point in a three-month cup base.

Nuance Communications (NUAN) jumped 5% after reporting its fiscal fourth-quarter results late Monday. Earnings, revenue and bookings all easily exceeded analyst consensus. The stock has been slogging through a 32-month correction.
Overseas, China's markets notched a mixed finish, with the Shanghai Composite up 1.4% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index down a fraction. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 edged up 0.3%.
In Europe, stocks were pushing uneven gains into midday trade, with Frankfurt's DAX up 1% and London's FTSE 100 ahead 0.1%.

The dollar gained vs. the euro and was down against the yen. The saga of disgruntled, and bankrupt, Apple supplier GT Advanced Technologies will go on at least a little longer than planned, after a court hearing to discuss a bankruptcy settlement between GT and Apple was postponed to Dec. 10 from Nov. 25.Unsecured creditors of GT Advanced sought the postponement to give them more time to investigate possible objections to the settlement. GT itself has agreed to the proposed settlement after offering some harsh words for the world's most valuable company.Bankruptcy court documents that GT had filed over the past month shine a light on the otherwise secretive relationship of Apple with its suppliers, or at least one supplier, though Apple (AAPL) denies most GT allegations.GT claims that its contract as an Apple supplier was "oppressive," driving it to declare Chapter 11 bankruptcy.GT says that it had to sign a nondisclosure agreement calling for a $50 million penalty for leaking information. GT made scratch-resistant sapphire glass display covers to be used for high-end versions of the Apple Watch, slated for release early next year. The sapphire displays had been expected to be used for the new iPhone 6, but so far Apple has stuck with Corning 's (GLW) Gorilla Glass for its iPhones.Apple has a very different perspective. It claims to have "bent over backwards" to work with GT Advanced, making payments even though the supplier "failed to meet performance milestones."Apple calls itself flexible in negotiations. The firm adds that many allegations by GT Advanced are false and defamatory, and "portray Apple as a coercive bully," according to court documents obtained by IBD.These details came to light after District of New Hampshire U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Henry Boroff unsealed the Apple supplier's court documents on Nov. 6, as the two companies were hashing out a settlement.Sought To Unseal DocumentsGT Advanced said that it had petitioned the court to allow it to reveal the nondisclosure details in the interest of creditors, equity holders and other stakeholders. It said that unsealing the details would ensure an "open, transparent and fair process."Apple is reputed to be a tough negotiator with great leverage in dealing with suppliers, and finding out specifics about its contracts can be impossible, says Srini Sundararajan, an analyst with Summit Research Partners."Often, the best way is to look at 10-Qs and 10-Ks of Apple's current and prior vendors, a laborious process," Sundararajan said. Even then, the documents aren't likely to include much information, he says.GT Advanced claims that Apple's nondisclosure agreements "provide that each breach of the confidentiality obligations will require (GT Advanced) to pay liquidated damages to Apple in an amount of $50 million per occurrence," according to the court documents.GT Advanced Chief Operating Officer Daniel Squiller said in an affidavit that his company had become a "captive supplier" of Apple, enduring "constant interference" and arbitrary changes in product specifications.GT Advanced said that it sold "every unit of sapphire material at a substantial loss," racked up as much as $900 million in expenses and had to lay off 1,300 workers.GT Advanced stock plummeted from 19.77 on June 28 to 80 cents when it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Oct. 6. It's now trading near 50 cents over-the-counter.Apple said in court documents that it will "continue evaluating GTAT's progress on larger sapphire boule development," and will help bankruptcy-affected employees find new jobs.GT Advanced claims that Apple told it to "put on your big boys pants and accept the agreement" when GT pressed its concerns about terms of its sapphire agreement, which it says was "strategically structured" to benefit Apple.GT Advanced also said that the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating its sapphire business and that it is cooperating with authorities.Apple said in its own filing that GT Advanced's allegations made by contain "extensive, unnecessary, scandalous and defamatory statements about Apple's alleged intent, motives and business tactics." The document says that many of GT Advanced's statements are "gratuitous, false and wholly irrelevant.""These statements are intended to vilify Apple and portray Apple as a coercive bully," Apple stated in court documents.Despite the harsh words, on Nov. 4 GT Advanced said in an SEC filing that it has signed an amended settlement agreement with Apple and is seeking bankruptcy court approval."We have been working diligently to develop a restructuring plan that will allow us to emerge from Chapter 11 as quickly as possible and with the operating flexibility and resources to position GT for long-term success," GT said in an Oct. 23 statement announcing the original settlement , which was amended on Nov. 5.GT Advanced plans to wind down its sapphire production and exit the market as a producer of sapphire materials to refocus as an equipment supplier and maker of products used to manufacturer sapphire as well as photovoltaic and polysilicon solar products. Apple will be able to recover $439 million in prepayments that it made to GT Advanced, say the documents.GT Advanced claims that it had to file for bankruptcy after the deal to provide sapphire for Apple's iPhones "collapsed."GT Advanced, which said that it has more than 40 years of experience developing "technological innovations in connection with the manufacturing of furnaces to grow sapphire for industrial use," added that it had signed a contract in October 2013 to install more than 2,000 sapphire-growing furnaces to be operated in a facility that Apple would provide. GT said that the transaction had the potential to be "revolutionary" for its business and a "significant achievement for Apple."Time And Money IssuesGT Advanced added that Apple had negotiated over price and terms, and agreed not to buy the furnaces. Instead, GT Advanced would borrow money from Apple to purchase furnace components and assemble furnaces that would grow sapphire for Apple, court documents said. Under the deal's terms, GT Advanced said that it was to acquire 2,036 sapphire furnaces using $578 million ($439 million were fully paid) in total prepayments from Apple.But GT Advanced said it could not produce the volume of sapphire "within the time frames the parties had agreed, and was more expensive than anticipated."Apple said that it had paid GT Advanced $439 million in prepayments and spent another $700 million-plus in connection with the transaction despite receiving "only a small fraction" of the original commitment of GT Advanced."Far from the villain in these Chapter 11 cases, Apple is the largest victim of the debtor's failure to perform under the agreements it negotiated at arms' length and with the advice of counsel," Apple stated in court documents.GT Advanced, however, claims that it could not modify its equipment, manufacturing processes or much of anything else without Apple's approval. GT also said that it had to offer Apple prices at least 5% below what it charged anyone else.Apple's contract instructed GT Advanced employees to refer to the sapphire display contract by the code name "Onyx," court documents said.Apple noted that the impact of its deal with GT Advanced included a stock price hike for GT."The price of a share of common stock of GT Advanced rose more than 20% upon the announcement by the debtors that they had entered into an agreement with Apple to supply sapphire," Apple said.
Hit by $137 million in unfavorable foreign currency translation, Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT) missed revenue views but topped earnings guidance during the third quarter.
Per-share earnings grew 27.9% to 87 cents, handily beating forecasts for 70 cents, while sales fell 6.9% to $4.66 billion, missing views for $4.93 billion.
Shares of the tire company rose 6% to 23.23 in the stock market today.

Tire unit volumes dropped 2% to 41.9 million year over year while original equipment unit volume fell 3% on reduced vehicle production in Brazil. Replacement tire shipments dipped 1% "primarily to a decline in North America where markets were disrupted due to significant stockpiling of imported low-end tires in advance of potential tariffs being imposed in 2015," said the company.
North America tire sales fell 6% to $2.1 billion. Tire sales in the Europe, Middle East and Africa segment dropped 8% to $1.6 billion, and Asia Pacific sales edged down 1% to $531 million.
Latin America was hit the hardest, with tire sales tumbling 14% to $451 million amid economic troubles in Venezuela that have affected a number of other companies.

Skyworks Solutions' (SWKS) increased chip content inside Apple's iPhone6 models prompted Canaccord Genuity on Monday to raise its target price to 64 from 62 and reiterate a buy rating.

"Based on our analysis, industry discussions and recent teardown reports, we believe Skyworks increased its dollar content share by more than 10% in the iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus devices vs. the iPhone 5s and iPhone 5c models and remains a key leading RF (radio frequency) supplier to Apple (AAPL)," Michael Walkley, an analyst with Canaccord Genuity, said in a research report on Monday.
Skyworks stock, however, was down nearly 3% in afternoon trading in the stock market today list of top-performing stocks despite tumbling more than 8% on Wednesday.

Canaccord's recent surveys indicate "extremely strong demand" for the iPhone 6 products that it says is likely to translate into strong Q4 sales and market share gains for Apple in the high-end smartphone market vs. Samsung and others.

Apple's iPhone 6 will go on sale in China on Oct. 17, about a month after hitting store shelves in the U.S. The iPhone 6 models will be available in 115 countries by year-end, Apple said. Weaker than expected 4G smartphone sales in China could be a reason Skyworks stock is down Monday, TheStreet said.

A look inside the iPhone 6 models by the tech-repair firm iFixit in Melbourne, Australia, on Sept. 19 revealed that Skyworks and other chip companies were the winners in supplying key components, while others missed out.

GT Advanced Technologies' (GTAT) sapphire glass was not incorporated into the new iPhones, and on Monday the company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Its stock was down 87% in afternoon trading, near 1.40.

Among other chipmakers benefitingfrom the iPhone6 models are Avago Technologies (AVGO), TriQuint Semiconductor (TQNT) and RF Micro Devices (RFMD). RF Micro and TriQuint await final regulatory approval for their merger to create a combined company named Qorvo.

As a rookie salesman, Harvey Firestone learned a vital lesson:
Focus energy on the big customer.
The result was a pumped-up life in business.
What did Firestone (1868-1938), who went on to create Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., mean by big?
The customer didn't necessarily have to own a big business. As Firestone put it, he or she could be on the way to having a big business.
The key, according to the son of a humble yet productive Ohio farming family, was to identify buyers who saw a chance to expand their business and boost sales fast.
Firestone grasped that point during his first job as a seller of vanilla flavorings, rose-scented lotions and other extracts for his employer and friend, O.D. Jackson.
Arriving in Apple Creek, a tiny town in northern Ohio, in the 1890s, Firestone spotted two general stores and several shops where he could sell his products.
Lacking confidence, he first tried the small stores. The owners flatly refused.
Not ready to give up, Firestone called on the owner of one of the big outlets. To the salesman's surprise, the busy boss made time to listen to his story, then made an order on the spot.

"Unless a man on the first approach shows signs of wanting to make money, it is a waste of time to try to convince him that he ought to buy," Firestone wrote in "Men and Rubber" with Samuel Crowther. "Thereafter, when I entered a town, I always tried the largest and not the smallest store first."
The Ford Drive

In 1905, after he co-founded a rubber tire company five years before that first served horse carriages and later cars and trucks, Firestone used that strategy to land a supply deal with Henry Ford for 2,000 sets of car tires.
It was Firestone's biggest order.
At the time, his firm was small fry — not big enough to join the G&J Clincher Tire Association.
Made up of well-established rubber-tire companies, the association worked like a monopoly. It set production quotas for each member firm and set prices uniformly.

The G&J also treated customers with arrogance. It offered Ford, who was on the verge of revolutionizing the car industry with mass production, a fixed price of $70 for a set of tires based on clincher technology, in which wheel collars held the tire in the rim's steel channel.

When Firestone heard that Ford aimed to make an order for 2,000 sets of tires, he sped to Detroit, met with the car magnate and pitched a better product that would cost only $55 (worth $1,450 now) per set.
Ford, after testing the tires, wrote Firestone the order.

Over nearly three decades, Firestone Tire achieved phenomenal growth. Sales at the Akron, Ohio-based firm bulged from $150,000 in 1902 to $115 million (worth $1.3 billion now) in 1920, a compounded annual growth rate of 44.6%.
By 1937, a year before Firestone's death, sales reached $157 million (or $2.5 billion today) while profit jumped to $9.2 million (worth $144 million now).

From 1900 to 1920, his company's workforce grew from 10 employees to 19,800. At one point, the shortage of Akron housing forced him to partner with rival companies and buy land to develop residential communities. This fostered worker loyalty.

During the Great Depression of the 1930s, many companies were crippled by union-backed strikes. Firestone avoided massive shutdowns by paying above-average wages and finding employees who enjoyed the challenge of working in a fast-growing industry.
"Firestone was one of the first among the big companies to work out accommodating contracts to unions," Daniel Nelson, professor emeritus of history at the University of Akron, told IBD.
He notes that in contrast, the 1936 strike at rival Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT) lasted until the start of World War II.
Japan's Bridgestone Group, a global tire maker, acquired Firestone Tire & Rubber in 1988.
Growing up in Columbiana in northeast Ohio, Firestone learned much about business just by observing his father, a small-time farmer.
The older Firestone, Harvey wrote, didn't necessarily work harder than other farmers in town. He just did things smarter.
Benjamin Firestone used a little more fertilizer than others to ensure high yields. He focused on cattle farming rather than dairy because it was more profitable and less labor-intensive.
And when he had a great year on the farm, he kept money in reserve to weather future bad harvests.
The son adopted a similar policy in the tire business.
Despite making a profit right from the beginning, he refused to pay shareholders a dividend. He plowed profit back into the firm to expand capacity, try new technology and hire more workers.
He also succeeded by sticking with a market on a roll: car tires.
"He saw the virtue of specialization of an industry," said Nelson. "B.F. Goodrich and U.S. Rubber fell behind by making a range of items, like raincoats, galoshes and hoses."
What else did Firestone do differently to achieve success?
• Innovated aggressively. By working closely with scientists and factory foremen, Firestone made solid-rubber tires that were higher in quality than the competition.
Even as his young company shifted sales and profit into high gear, Firestone focused on the new technology of air-filled tires.
Such tires became the standard in bicycles but busted under the weight of horse-drawn buggies.
Now with the car industry in the fast lane, Firestone knew he had to incorporate the technology to keep and expand his customer base.
So he employed the brightest engineers he could find. This led to the development of mountable tire rims, letting car owners easily replace air-filled tires.
Result: more driving, more tire sales.
• Chose managers carefully. The company boss wanted thoughtful, not loudmouth, talent.

He did not want "the kind of man who can give me an instant decision on anything I may bring up, for, if he has not had the opportunity to give the question serious thought, then he is only guessing," Firestone wrote.
• Reserved time to think. In 1920, the U.S. economy froze after booming during the 1914-18 First World War. Sales orders were canceled across a bevy of industries, including car tires.
Firestone was vacationing in Europe and suddenly received a cable saying the company's bankers wouldn't lend a penny more. Production stopped due to no sales.
Firestone rushed back to Ohio to learn that his firm owed $43 million, worth $483 million today.
Deliveries for rubber and other raw materials were coming in with no money to pay for them.
Stacks of tires lay like bricks inside the company factories.

After listening to his brass on a Friday morning, Firestone told his staff that he needed time alone to think it over. He spent the weekend on his farm, then returned with a plan that shocked his team: Cut the price of tires by 25%. Now.
Managers voiced disagreement, but Firestone refused to budge.
The fire sale worked.

In September and October alone, Firestone Tire & Rubber sold $18 million worth of merchandise. That cash slashed the company's outstanding borrowing from $43 million to $31 million — or $273 million today.
By Oct. 31, 1924, the firm had wiped out all debt.
Tighten Operations

Firestone realized operations needed smart cost cutting. The office force fell from 1,000 to 300. The statistics department shrank from 35 employees to three, without a drop in the quality of data needed to make proper decisions.

"Thought, not money, is the real business capital," he wrote.
